It is well known that some metastatic infiltrative lobular carcinomas may mimic diffuse non-Hodgkin's lymphomas. A retrospective survey of breast carcinomas with axillary nodal metastases showed that 'nodular sclerosing' nodal tumours were restricted to cases of infiltrating lobular carcinoma of the breast. The presence and distribution of the pentraxin known as amyloid P component (AP) in the human adult breast was studied using a direct immunohistochemical technique. AP was invariably present. It was constantly associated with elastic fibres and with areas of elastosis. AP was not detected in any of the epithelial basement membranes. From these and other studies it is evident that AP is not particular to amyloid disease but is ordinarily a constituent of both normal and disease-affected connective tissues. The pentraxin known as amyloid P component (AP) is ordinarily present in human adult connective tissues. An identical, or closely similar, macromolecule is present in human adult serum but only very low levels are detectable in umbilical w r d blood. It was therefore decided to investigate the presence of AP in connective tissues of the very young. This was done using a direct immunofluorescent technique on frozen sections of skin from a series of obstetric. surgical and post mortem specimens. AP was not detected in foetal, neonatal or very young infant dermis. It was first detectable in the third year of life and approximated to the adult pattern by the fourth year, In this respect AP differs from other known connective tissue ligands, such as fibronectin and laminin, which first appear early in foetal development.

Human breast tumours are difficult to establish as cell lines in vitro. Nonetheless, over 40 purportedly human breast tumour cell lines have been reported, and proved of some value in laboratory studies of human breast carcinoma. With few exceptions these cell lines are essentially monomorphic in tissue culture. In contrast, PMC42, a novel human breast tumour cell line established from a pleural effusion of a patient with metastatic breast cancer, exhibits an extremely pleomorphic growth pattern in monolayer culture. Eight morphological cell types have been observed, in both phase contrast and electron microscopic studies. The relationship between these cell types and those found in the normal and neoplastic human breast will be discussed with reference to the possibility of PMC42 representing a stem cell population.

Human breast epithelium when grown in monolayer culture rapidly loses many of its recognisable differentiated characteristics; even in 3-dimensional cultures in collagen gels there is a significant change in the appearance of the cells with notably a loss of organised myofilaments in myoepithelial cells, and the acquisition of tonofilaments. Human breast organoids obtained by enzymatic digestion of reduction mammoplasties and identical to those used to prepare cultures, have now been established in immunologically incompetent mice. Using antibodies to keratin, myosin, laminin and type IV collagen it has been possible to demonstrate the maintenance of the normal relationship between epithelial and myoepithelial cells with the production of basement membrane materials. The epithelium continues to proliferate beyond 3 mth and the distribution of monoclonal antibodies which react with luminal membrane antigens, e.g. M8 and M18, is as reported in the normal resting breast. This model is being studied in conjunction with in vitro techniques to define the responses of the buman tissue to both physiological and carcinogenic manipulations.

It has previously been shown that the monoclonal antibody, Cal, reacts with most malignant cells but few normal cells. The epitope to which it binds has been designated Ca. Using the Cal monoclonal, it will be shown that Ca is expressed in normal placenta, apocrine glands, sweats ducts, sebaceous glands, type I1 pneumocytes of lung, and epithelia of fallopian tube and urinary tract. It is also found in certain non-neoplastic conditions of breast and cervix. In the latter tissues the staining reaction was confined to the membrane of cells. By comparison in malignant preinvasive lesions of cervix, and possibly breast, Ca is cytoplasmic and membrane in distribution. Therefore, the qualitative expression of this antigen differs in malignancy and in non-neoplastic disorders. Furthermore it will also be shown that Cal reacts with all secondary cancers found in bone marrow so far examined. These malignant cells, whether isolated or in clusters, all express positive membrane and cytoplasmic staining. No cells in normal marrow, or in marrow disorders per se, react with Cal. This indicates that Cal screening of marrow is a much more effective way of picking up malignant cells than standard technology. The distinction between reactive and neoplastic mesothelium is often difficult to make using standard histological techniques. Since it has been suggested that the Cal antibody may be helpful in the diagnosis of malignancy, we have assessed its value in a series of needle biopsies of pleura where the pathological diagnosis has been confidently established. We studied a total of 24 cases; 11 of these were proven mesotheliomas, 8 contained purely reactive mesothelium and five were metastatic carcinomas. All the blocks examined were formalin-fixed and paraffin-embedded and each was stained by an indirect immunoperoxidase method using an antibody concentration of 0.5~~g/ml. 7 out of 11 mesotheliomas examined and 4 out of 8 reactive biopsies showed positive staining. Of the five metastatic carcinomas two adenocarcinomas (from colon and ovary) and one squamous cell carcinoma stained positively. However, another squamous cell carcinoma and a small cell anaplastic carcinoma failed to stain. There was no appreciable difference in the pattern of staining between reactive and neoplastic mesothelium. In both instances staining was focal; in all positive cases cell membrane staining was present and in several cases cytoplasmic staining was also seen. These results suggest that the Cal antibody is of little value in distinguishing malignant from reactive mesothelium.

There is a radial arrangement of hyperplastic or cystic parenchyma around an elastotic distorted centre containing haphazardly scattered ductules. Study of biopsy and mastectomy material discloses a general incidence of about lo%, most commonly at age 40-60 yr and also occurring bilaterally. Found both singly and in large numbers scattered throughout the breast, they are usually less than 5 mm and only rarely as much as 10 mm. Although readily recognised from their elastotic centre, supravital staining and subgross stereomicroscopy greatly assist identification of early stages. Ultrastructural studies show myofibroblasts at the centre of the lesion in early phases of development which probably occurs at the point of duct branching. There is also an unusual disturbance in the organisation of the epithelial stromal junction, with focal disruption of the basal lamina and deposition of filamentous and fibrillary material including collagen and elastin. The consequences of impaired parenchymal stromal barriers may be significant when associated with persistent or renewed myofibroblast activity. distinguishing between malignant and nonmalignant lesions. Each was stained with the immunoperoxidase method using the Cal antibody at a concentration of 50pg/ml. The cytoplasm, free border, and luminal content components were systematically graded; both duct and acinar epithelium were scored separately. Review of these sections showed that the Cal antibody invariably stained at least one of these components in all 20 normal breasts examined. We have studied a series of 10 biopsies of mammary Paget's disease, together with sections of the tumours from the same patients' mastectomy specimens, using two commercially prepared monoclonal antibodies raised to human milk fat globulin membrane (HMFG-1 & 2). These antibodies stain normal and neoplastic mammary epithelium and do not stain normal epidermis. A third monoclonal antibody (L61), with specificity for cytokeratins, was also employed in this series. Formalin fixed paraffin wax embedded sections of routine biopsy material were stained using an antimouse Idperoxidase conjugate as the second antibody. In all cases the neoplastic breast epithelial cells showed variable surface and cytoplasmic staining, whilst the normal duct epithelial cells showed surface staining only with HMFG-1 & 2. Cytoplasmic staining of intra-epidermal Paget's cells was seen with both of these antibodies. Therefore Paget's cells present in the epidermis exhibit antigens characteristic of neoplastic breast epithelium. This is supportive evidence for a ductal origin of intra-epidermal Paget's cells.

body_text.text: The glucocorticoid receptor is believed to play an important role in mediating the therapeutic effects of glucocorticoids in the treatment of leukaemias and lymphomas. However investigation of the precise mode of action of this cytoplasmic protein is restricted by the current inability to detect its presence in a steroid-free environment. To provide an alternative method of detection and assay, which avoids the use of radiolabelled glucocorticoids, a monoclonal antibody to the rat glucocorticoid receptor has been produced. The heat-activated glucocorticoid-receptor complex from rat liver has been isolated and partially purified by affinity chromatography on DNA-cellulose. BALB/c mice were immunised with repeated doses of the purified preparation the spleen cells isolated and fused with NS1 mouse myeloma cells using polyethylene glycol. The hybrid cells were cloned and those producing antibodies against the receptor identified by radioimmunoassay and subsequently injected into BALB/c mice to generate ascites tumours yielding substantial quantities of monoclonal antibodies. Each of these antibodies is being characterised to confirm its specific glucocorticoid receptor binding activity and to establish the antigenic site and the affinity to various physiological forms of the receptor. The antibodies will be used for histochemical and biochemical analysis of receptor distribution and function in cells and tumours of varying glucocorticoid sensitivity.

body_text.text: Twenty steroids, selected for their general similarity in chemical structure to the natural glucocorticoid hydrocortisone, were tested for their capacity to suppress pre-S-phase growth of lymphocytes after PHA stimulation of peripheral blood mononuclear cells from normal donors. Hydrocortisone and the 5 analogues, with hydroxyl groups at positions, l l p , 17a and 21, all had similar potency as assessed by the slope of the log dose response for reduction in numbers of cells responding to stumulation and so it was concluded that these compounds had a similar action at the cellular level. Compounds with only 2 hydroxyl groups at any of the combination of positions l l p , 17a or 21 had a lower potency for suppression of lymphocyte activation and compounds with one or no substitution at these positions were virtually inactive. This assay tests the response of human cells in uitro, it may reflect immunosuppressive action in uiuo better than animal experimentation and could be used to screen new compounds for glucocorticoid activity.

body_text.text: The finding of focal collections of lymphocytes within the thyroid gland is not an uncommon finding but is of uncertain relevance. Previous studies have shown a prevelance of lymphocytic thyroiditis which varies with age, sex and ethnic origin and shows a variable relationship to the presence of thyroglobulin and microsomal autoantibodies. 163 thyroid glands were removed at post-mortem from unselected adult patients in two Southampton hospitals over a 6-mth period. The whole glands were weighed, sliced and examined histologically to determine the presence and severity of thyroiditis, the results being expressed morphometrically using a simple technique involving a microcomputer, a digitiser pad and a projecting microscope. The clinical notes were reviewed in each case. Autoantibody levels were retrieved from the notes if performed within a year of death. In a small proportion of cases antibody titres were established by analysing samples of blood taken at post-mortem. In women the mean thyroid mass was 18.7 g whilst in men it was 22.4 g. Varying degrees of thryoiditis were prc;ent in 56% of women and 24% of men. The significance of these findings and the autoantibody results will be discussed and related to previous reports of similar studies on other ethnic groups.

Wyllie Department of Pathology, University of Edinburgh, Edinburgh Apoptotic cells are rapidly phagocytosed either by tissue macrophages or by adjacent epithelial cells. In this study the changes on the surface of an apoptotic cell leading to its recognition by macrophages were investigated. An in uitro assay was established that allowed quantification of the binding of Balb/c mouse thymocytes to Balbk mouse peritoneal macrophages. Thymocytes rendered apoptotic by exposure to methyl prednisolone in culture bound in significantly greater numbers than did non-apoptotic thymocytes. This binding could be fully inhibited by N-acetyl glucosamine but not by mannose, suggesting a role for a macrophage surface lectin. The binding was neither temperature nor serum dependent. There were definite differences between the characteristics of the binding of damaged erythrocytes and of apoptotic thymocytes to peritoneal macrophages. This indicates that the recognition of altered self cellsa prerequisite for their phagocytosismay be mediated by several different nonimmunological mechanisms. The signals whereby senescent erythrocytes are recognised by macrophages and removed from the circulation are poorly understood. However, both Fc and C3 receptors as well as the galactose binding lectin on the surface of the macrophage have been implicated. Human erythrocytes incubated in normal saline at 37" for 24 h were used as a putative model for senescent erythrocytes and their binding in uitro to Balb/c mouse peritoneal macrophages was quantified. Little binding of fresh erythrocytes was observed, whilst saline injured erythrocytes were bound in large numbers. This binding was not mediated by macrophage Fc or C3 receptors. Free galactose in the medium did not inhibit binding but partial inhibition was obtained with L-fucose and to a lesser extent with N-acetyl glucosamine, arabinose and N-acetyl galactosamine. The binding was temperature and divalent cation dependent and inhibited by sodium azide. The results show that macrophage recognition of damaged cells does not require serum factors and if macrophage surface lectins are involved the specificity depends upon structures more complex than a single monosaccharide.

body_text.text: Previous investigations of Langerhans cells in uiuo and in vitro have concentrated upon demonstrating whether or not these cells are lymphoid, myeloid, epidermal, or melanocytic. Accepting the evidence that they are macrophages of the skin and represent a lymphomedullary rather than an epithelial cell type, their precise functional role in the in uiuo immune response remains uncertain. To try to clarify this role a method has been devised to extract these cells from the epidermis of inbred mice. The cells isolated from the skin express Ia and bear FC and C3 reactors and have membrane ATPase activity. They have dendritic rather than macrophage morphology. However, in in uitro assays the Langerhans cell clearly differs from both macrophages and dendritic cells. These findings suggest that the Langerhams cell is a different phenotypic variant in the macrophage/dendritic cell accessory system. Specialised for the uptake of antigen and transport to the lymph node rather than for antigen presentation.

Pigment was identifiable in neonatal animals and occurred in the absence of any other abnormality. Its appearance under the light microscope and its tinctorial and histochemical properties indicate that it can be classified with the lipofuscins. Ultrastructural studies have shown that the pigment is contained within lysosomes. Susceptibility to pigmentation showed dominant autosomal inheritance. body_text.text: We disaggregated human osteoclastomas and found that large numbers of osteoclasts were released into suspension. We found t h a t the osteoclasts demonstrate an identical response to calcitonin and prostaglandins to that previously observed in rat osteoclasts. We prepared slices of human cortical bone using a diamond-impregnated wheel, and settled osteoclasts onto these slices. We found that the osteoclasts formed characteristic pits and depressions in the bone surface during incubation. Bone resorption by these osteoclasts appeared to be intermittent, with alternating episodes of resorption and migration leaving 'footprints' of resorbed bone. Although both organic and mineral components of bone were resorbed, bone mineral was resorbed more deeply, leaving organic fibres lining the surface of the pit. Our observations are compatible with the view that the mineral component of bone is responsible for the initiation of enzyme release by osteoclasts: when mineral is resorbed beyond the organic component the osteoclast ceases resorption and recommences migration until fresh exposed mineral is contacted. This technique makes it possible, for the first time, to analyse the properties of the substrate which induce bone-resorptive behaviour in osteoclasts, and to assess the direct and indirect effects of hormones and cells on the induction, stimulation and inhibition of osteoclastic bone resorption.

Asynchronous CV-1 cells were compared with cells synchronised by hydroxyurea in early S-phase, in their response to infectious SV40 virus, or to purified SV40 DNA 'transfected' with calcium phosphate. body_text.text: Many chemical and physical agents have been shown to induce testicular atrophy in rodents. In many instances the target cell within the testis has not been identified, but in cases where it has, one of the most susceptible cells appears to be the primary spermatocyte. This is the predominant cell type affected by a diverse range of agents including heat, dinitropyrolles, nitrobenzene, actinomycin D and hypophysectomy. It was also found to be the primary site of cellular toxicity in a study which investigated the histological development of testicular atrophy induced by ethylene glycol monoalkyl ethers in the rat. These compounds are extensively used as solvents in the food and chemical industries. When ethylene glycol monomethyl ether was administered orally at 500 mg/kg/d for 11 days all stages of spermatocyte development from zygotene through to secondary spermatocytes showed degenerative changes. As the dose level was decreased or the duration of dosing reduced, a differential susceptibility, dependant on the precise stage of meiotic maturation became evident. An order of sensitivity was established: dividing spermatocytes > early pachytene spermatocytes > late pachytene spermatocytes > mid pachytene spermatocytes > zygotene spermatocytes. Prolonged dosing resulted in a maturation arrest of the spermatocytes at the zygotene stage.

In this study we have investigated NSE, SlOO, NF, brain tubulins and GFAP immunoreactivity (ir) in the diffuse neuroendocrine system of the gut. Antibodies to 68 K NF, 150 K NF, GFAP, brain tubulins, NSE and SlOO were used to immunostain samples from rat stomach, small intestine and colon. NF and NSEir were found in ganglion cells and in nerves running through muscle layers and the mucosa (lamina propria). In addition, endocrine cells were consistently stained with NSE antibodies. GFAP and SlOO were found in glial cells and in nerve bundles, mostly located in the muscle and submucosal layer. Brain tubulins were stained preferentially in ganglion cell bodies and large nerve bundles in the enteric wall supporting the hypothesis that brain tubulins exhibit specific antigenic properties in neural cells. We conclude that the investigation of the presence and localisation of neural markers in the periphery could represent a fundamental tool in the delineation of the diffuse neuroendocrine system of the gut in health and disease.

body_text.section: VIP AND PHI: CO-LOCALISATION IN THE HUMAN ENTERIC NERVOUS SYSTEM

body_text.text: PHI (peptide with histidine at the N-terminal and isoleucine at the C-terminal), a newly discovered peptide, shows sequence homology and has several actions in common with VIP. In view of these similarities, the distributions of the two peptides were compared in the human gut using immunocytochemistry . Specimens of colon were immunostained with specific antibodies to natural PHI and VIP. Immunostaining was quenched by absorption of each antiserum with the corresponding peptide (10 nmol/ml) but not diminished by addition of VIP to the PHI antiserum or PHI to the VIP antibodies. PHIimmunoreactivity occurred exclusively in nerves, which were similar in appearance and distribution to those containing VIP-immunoreactivity, but were less numerous. The nerves were present in each layer of the colonic wall and PHI-immunoreactive ganglion cells were seen in the sub-mucous plexus. Examination of serial 3 Fm sections revealed four apparent cell populations. Those containing VIP formed approximately 50% of all ganglion cells. Roughly one-half of these also contained PHI. The third most numerous type were non-immunoreactive cells whilst a minor population displayed predominantly PHI immunoreactivity. Thus, variable concentrations of these peptides occur within neurons. It can be concluded that some ganglion cells of the human gut contain PHI and VIP, indicating their possible co-storage or common origin from a single precursor molecule. body_text.text: The use of oesophageal transection in the treatment of bleeding oesophageal varices has provided the opportunity to study tissue from the site of bleeding. Dilated intraepithelial blood filled channels have been found in all oesophageal transection specimens from patients with oesophageal varices. Larger blood filled channels lying immediately beneath the squamous epithelium were also common. Comparison of histological findings in sections of transection rings from 27 patients with varices and rings from a control groups of 17 patients undergoing oesophageal transection and anastomosis following tumour resection was carried out. The number and area of both intra-epithelial and sub-epithelial channels, the length of intra-epithelial papillae and thickness of squamous epithelium was significantly increased in the varices group (P<O.OS). The intra-epithelial channels appear to be derived from capillary vessels within papillae but electron microscopy indicated that they are lined by flattened squamous cells rather than endothelial cells and no basement membrane has been demonstrated. These channels may correspond to the 'cherry red' spots described by endoscopists in patients with oesphageal varices. The relevance of the channels with regard to bleeding will be discussed.

body_text.text: Thc solitary ulcer of the rectum syndrome (SURS) is a well recognized entity; characteristically it is a benign self limiting condition occurring in young adults. The histological and histochemical features of this lesion have been well documented. In this paper, 19 cases of classical SURS and 20 cases of overt colonic or rectal prolapse are described. Similarities in the histological and histochemical features between these groups lead us to suggest that there is a range of large bowe1,disorders which result from stretching or prolapse of mucosa. SURS is a distinct clinicopathological entity within this spectrum and we propose that the term 'mucosal prolapse syndrome' be used to encompass SURS and related disorders which have this underlying pathogenetic mechanism.

body_text.text: Department of Pathology, University of Bristol. Bristol BS8 1 T D Vascular elastosis is a feature of invasive ileal carcinoid tumours. In view of the prognostic significance of vascular invasion in colonic carcinoma, the elastic fibre response in colorectal carcinoma may have prognostic implications. This study wa3 designed to investigate elastic fibre proliferation in colorectal carcinoma, colonic diverticulitis, ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease of the colon. The elastosis of colorectal carcinoma was strictly focal, periadventitial and limited to the core of largebowel carcinomas. Elastic fibre proliferation in colonic diverticulitis, ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease was more generalised in fibrous connective tissue, smooth muscle and around the venous adventitia. These morphological observations suggest that chemical elastogenic factors in carcinoma and colonic inflammation differ in their diffusibility, target cells and, possibly, in their mode of activation of elastin-synthesizing cells. There are interesting similarities to and differences from elastotic reactions in the breast. The biological and pathological significance of the findings will be discussed.

body_text.text: Spirochaetosis of the human gastrointestinal tract is a well described phenomenon but doubt is still expressed about the pathological significance of this infestation. Nevertheless reports of intestinal spirochaetosis continue to appear in the literature, often in patients who have undergone rectal biopsy or appendicectomy and in whom spirochaetosis is the only abnormality detected. We present 7 cases of spirochaetosis of t.he appendix or rectum and discuss them in terms of their clinical history and treatment. We have also studied these cases histologically, immunocytochemically and by scanning and transmission electron microscopy, Two patients were practising male homosexuals but no obvious clinical pattern emerged from the group as a whole. Whilst the spirochaetes were present on non-inflamed mucosa, the microvilli were apparently partly replaced by spirochaetes. These findings provide further evidence for the suggestion that the disturbance of colonic fluid balance and the diarrhoea often associated with spirochaetosis may be a consequence of the observed depletion of microvilli. lesion is made difficult by the coincidental induction of hepatocellular carcinoma. Coumarin is reported to induce cholangiofibrosis and cholangiocarcinoma without the parallel development of hepatocellular tumours and so we have studied the histogenesis of the coumarin lesion in an attempt to circumvent this problem. In rats given diets containing 0.5% coumarin and killed at intervals to 18 mth there was extensive damage to hepatocytes in the centrilobular region followed by fine bile duct proliferation extending between adjacent portal area and between portal areas and central veins. Focal proliferation of ducts and fibrous tissue was associated with mucus accumulation in the lumen of the ducts and finally with intestinal metaplasia. Growth of the lesion resulted in destruction of normal hepatic architecture with extensive fibrosis. There was no evidence of local invasion or of extra-hepatic metastasis and progression to cholangiocarcinoma was not seen.

body_text.text: A spontaneous liver disease, early symptoms of which are ascites, jaundice or polyphagia, has been seen in 18 cats over a period of 15 yr in the Bristol School of Veterinary Science. Cats were between six mth and 10 yr old; 12 being only 4 yr old or less. Both sexes were affected and no particular breed predilection was noted. The disease was characterised by variable progression, hypergammaglobulinaemia and often an associated lymphadenopathy. Mitochondria1 antibodies were not found and only one low-titre antinuclear antibody was detected in the series. Evidence of extrahepatic biliary obstruction, arthropathy, the sicca syndrome and enteritis or colitis were lacking. Grossly the livers displayed a fine nodularity with vascular distension. Histologically the liver biopsies and post-mortem material showed prominent lymphoid nodules in the portal tracts, deranged blood vessels, monolobular fibrous banding, and bile ductal mononuclear inflammation and destruction. Bile ductular proliferation was often a prominent feature. In some cases a concentric periductal fibrosis was found around bile ducts. Less frequent were centrilobular sinusoidal distension, cholestasis, erosion of limiting plates and fatty change. Comparisons will be drawn between this condition and apparently similar human and animal liver diseases.

body_text.text: Simultaneous administration of phenobarbitone and ngaione results in the induction of cirrhosis in young male rats within 4 to 5 wk. Ngaione specifically causes injury to the periportal parenchymal cells under these conditions and the initial fibrogenic reaction takes place in this zone. This is followed by rapid development of regeneration nodules in the periportal zone which becomes separated from the apparentty normal centrilobular zone by a continuous midzonal band of connective tissue. With time and increase in the ngaione dose, the cells of the centrilobular zone remote from the central vein gradually undergo degeneration and necrosis at the midzonal margin, allowing the zone of fibrous tissue to increase in width. Finally, the centrilobular parenchyma is completely lost and entirely replaced by new connective tissue. The liver then consists of regeneration nodules which are resistant to the toxic ngaione, and connective tissue containing the hepatic vasculature and bile ducts and ductulesnamely, the complete picture of cirrhosis. Apart from the short time needed to produce the model, few, if any, animals become sick or die in the course of development of the lesion, and for a substantial part of the induction period the metobolically important centrilobular parenchymal zone remains undamaged. This is in contrast to what occurs with CCI, and other well-known hepatotoxic agents which specifically and extensively damage the centrilobular zone and which often results in low yields of cirrhotic animals.

body_text.text: School of Medicine, University College, London Investigation of the stages of neoplasia requires systems that are simple and free of extraneous tissue injury, rather than protracted and traumatic procedures such as prolonged feeding of carcinogen, feeding of several different toxic chemicals, or partial hepatectomy. We find that a single dose of diethylnitrosamine (DEN 30 mg/kg ip) or of dimethyl nitrosamine (DMN 15 mg/kg ip) given to Wister rats at lOOg body weight, and followed 1 wk later by administration of 0.1% Na Phenobarbitone in the drinking water and continued for 14 mth, leads to induction of a high yield of hyperplastic nodules and hepatocellular carcinomas. Neither nodules nor carcinomas were observed at this time in control rats given the nitrosamines or phenobarbitone alone. In previous work we added a dietary change to the system in order to induce cell division soon after nitrosamine administration. This step is unnecessary for maximum tumour production using 30 mg/kg DEN. However, using 15 mg/kg DMN we find that adding dietary change produces hyperplastic nodules and/or carcinoma in all animals, 415 having carcinomas, while in the absence of dietary change, although almost all animals have hyperplastic nodules, only 2/11 of these had carcinoma. It is clear that the rat liver provides a suitable simple model of chemical two-stage carcinogenesis.

body_text.text: Department of Pathology, University of Leeds, Leeds LSZ 9JT Over the past decade it has been shown that most tumour cell surface membranes carry specific tumour-associated antigens or a change in the pattern of glycoproteins expressed. We have therefore chosen to study the cell surface proteins of several cultured lymphoid tumour lines for the presence of specific antigens or changes in the glycoprotein patterns compared to normal cells. The surface glycoproteins of 2 lymphoblastoid, 2 lymphoma, 2 leukaemia and 1 myeloma cell lines were radiolabelled with using the Iodogen method. After being hypotonically swollen the cells were homogenised to remove the cell membranes which were then purified using sucrose gradient centrifugation. The membranes were solubilised in SDS prior to electrophoresis on SDS-gradient polyacrylamide slab gels which after fixation and stairing were dried onto filter paper and used for autoradiography. The results obtained on the autoradiographs will be discussed. Since 1979 fresh tissue from all lymph node biopsies received in the University Department of Pathology in Leeds has been stored in liquid nitrogen. During this period 131 lymph nodes have been subjected to cryostat sectioning and staining with a variety of monoclonal antibodies. The antibodies used were directed against immunoglobulins, Tcell subsets, Ia antigens and endothelium. Antibody localisation was demonstrated by an indirect immunoperoxidase technique and all of these sections were assessed independently by 2 observers. Polyclonal staining of immunoglobulin light chains was observed in all patients with Hodgkin's disease and nodes exhibiting reactive hyperplasia. The presence of light chain restriction was used to define the B-cell non-Hodgkin's lymphomas; in these cases the commonest phenotype was IgM, D heavy chains and either kappa or lambda light chains. None of the B-cell lymphomas exhibited both kappa and lambda staining. Some preliminary information will be given about the response to treatment in groups defined by their cell surface membrane phenotype.

body_text.text: Lymphomas composed predominantly of large cells have in the past been designated 'reticulum cell sarcomas', and more recently 'histiocytic sarcomas'. These tuqours present major diagnostic difficulties both in their separation from anaplastic carcinomas and in the identification of individual subtypes within the group. We have analysed 50 large cell lymphomas and two metastatic anaplastic carcinomas submitted to the Wessex Regional Lymphoma Registry. In addition to routine histological techniques the lymphomas were also studied by immunohistochemistry and in some cases the immunological phenotype was further determined on dispersed tumour cells. The majority of tumours were of B-cell lineage but significant numbers were T-cell lymphomas or of macrophage/monocyte lineage. We assessed the accuracy with which the immunological phenotype could be predicted from the morphology. The diagnostic value of other factors such as the presence of eosinophils, plasma cells and histiocytes and the vascularity of the tumour was also evaluated. The results of this study will be presented and discussed.

body_text.text: Primary lymphomas of the stomach represent a small proportion of all gastric malignancies but they are an important group because they behave differently and have a much better prognosis than carcinomas. We studied 38 cases of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma of the stomach which presented over an 8 yr period in Southampton General Hospital. 29 cases were primary lymphomas of the stomach; in 9 cases there was evidence of a tumour originating from organs other than stomach. On morphological grounds, all cases were classified as follicle centre cell lymphomas. 19 were centroblastid centrocytic follicular, follicular and diffuse or diffuse. 11 were centroblastic follicular and diffuse or diffuse and 8 were centrocytic. Immunohistochemical staining of paraffin sections showed monotypic immunoglobulin in the cells of 5 of the centroblastickentrocytic lymphomas, 4 of which showed plasmacytic differentiation. The plasma cells had the same immunological phenotype as the follicle centre cells. 8 of the 11 centroblastic lymphomas showed cytoplasmic immunoglobulin but only 1 of the 8 centrocytic tumours was positive. The origin of gastric lymphomas from mucosa associated lymphoid tissue will be discussed.

body_text.text: Three anti-B lymphocyte monoclonal antisera of known specificity, FMCl, FMC7 and B1 have been applied to suspensions of Hodgkin's disease tissue rich in Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells. A biotin avidin horseradish peroxidase technique was used to localise sera both in thin section for light microscopy and ultrathin section for electron microscopy. The morphological quality of such preparations facilitated accurate cellular identification in which positive membrane staining was precise and well defined. Biopsy material was obtained from four patients with Hodgkin's disease, two with the nodular sclerosing type and two mixed cellularity disease. In all of the four cases, each of the anti-B cell sera labelled approximately 80% of RS cells. It would thus appear that a high proportion of RS cells share antigens in commm with B-lymphocytes.

We have recently described a new procedure, the immunogold-silver staining (IGSS) method, which permits demonstration of these antigens in paraffin sections. In further studies we have employed a variety of reagents to treat sections prior to immunostaining by the IGSS and PAP techniques. The results show that the staining of surface membrane immunoglobulins by the IGSS method may be enhanced and that reliable demonstration of these antigens can be obtained also with the PAP technique. Macrophages were identified using nonspecific esterase and acid phosphatase staining and measurements were made of the total numbers of macrophages, macrophage area, integrated optical density and the total area of the staining was expressed as a percentage. The cases comprised 19 patients with Hodgkin's disease, 11 high grade lymphomas, 6 follicular lymphomas, 7 diffuse welldifferentiated lymphocytic lymphomas and 12 reactive lymph nodes. In the non-specific esterase stained sections there appeared to be no difference in the number of the macrophages in the various histological groups but in the acid phosphatase stained sections both Hodgkin's disease and the high grade lymphomas appeared to have much higher macrophage counts than the low grade lymphomas. Mean counts varied from 172 in the diffuse well-differentiated lymphocytic group up to 421 in the Hodgkin's disease patients. There was a statistically significant correlation between counts as assessed by acid phosphatase staining and the count measured by non-specific esterase staining. In the final stage of the project a colour graphic package was used to analyse and display the data and the usefulness of this approach will be demonstrated.

body_text.text: In an attempt to compare pre-operative pulmonary function test with measurements of small airways made on the resected specimen, currently available techniques for preparing and quantifying small airways have been assessed and new techniques developed. All previous studies have used paraffin embedded tissue sections giving considerable shrinkage (area loss 29%, linear loss 16%) and compression artefacts (area loss 11%, linear loss in direction of cut 7%). In our hands glycol methacrylate embedded sections provide shrinkage and compression free sections. Inability to apply constant pressure fixation to small surgical specimens has been overcome by the way in which data is handled. Selection of airways for morphometric measurements is considerably complicated by angle of cut and the effects of disease processes. This problem has been overcome by sampling from standard areas close to the pleura and by excluding the 30% most elliptical airways from all cases. Using the data on basement membrane circumference combined with the maximum to minimum diameter ratios it is possible to create a theoretical lumen area for each airway on the bais of constructing a smooth ellipse of equivalent circumference and maximum to minimum diameter ratio. The ratio of measured to theoretical lumen area may be indicative of airway tone in life. We have studied the peripheral airway epithelium of 16 smokers and 4 non-smokers in surgically resected specimens with 1 p. Toluidine blue stained araldite sections for light microscopy and by electron microscopy. Goblet cells were found in the bronchioles and terminal bronchioles of both smokers and non-smokers. A significant increase in goblet cell number was noted in the bronchioles of smokers (mean 6.7% of total epithelial cells) compared to non-smokers (mean 1.2% of total epithelial cells, PcO.01). In terminal and respiratory bronchioles the goblet cells were again more fequent in smokers but this failed to reach statistical significance. Clara cells were present in all patients in bronchioles, terminal bronchioles and respiratory bronchioles. In bronchioles. the Clara cells were significantly more frequent in non-smokers (mean 8.3% of total epithelial cells) than in smokers (mean 4.3% of total epithelial cells, P<O.Ol). Similarly there were significantly more Clara cells in terminal and respiratory bronchioles of non-smokers. It appears that cigarette smoke causes peripheral extension of goblet cells with a decrease in number of Clara cells.

body_text.text: Apparently normal lung tissue was collected at thoracotomy from 10 smoking and 5 nonsmoking patients. Fragments of lung were pulse labelled for 1 h with tritiated (3Hmethyl) thymidine using short-term in uitro culture technique under conditions of hyperbaric oxygenation at 3 atmospheres pressure. Tissue was embedded in glycol methacrylate and cut at 2 F for autoradiography and additional tissue embedded in araldite after osmification and cut at 1 p and used to aid in the identification of the cell population. Fragments of lung tissue ranging in size from 1 mm3 to 150 mm3 were found to have good penetration of label throughout the fragments and did not show the 'rim' effect which we have previously seen with fragments of tumour under comparable conditions. Of the cells with labelled nuclei the largest proportion (48%) were found in the interstitial compartment of the lung, comprising: fibroblasts, smooth muscle monocytes, pericytes and mast cells. As expected, of the two types of alveolar epithelium; the type I1 pneumocytes accounted for the great majority of the labelled cells. Similar proportions of endothelial cells in alveolar walls were labelled and a small number of inflammatory and airway epithelial cells (less than 8%). 10% of the labelled cells could not be clearly indentified. There were no differences in the proportions of labelled cells between smokers and non-smokers. NSE has been found in neurons and neuronendocrine cells throughout the body. In neurons of the central nervous system, NSE-immunostaining has been correlated with maturation, appearing late in development. We therefore investigated the developmental pattern of NSE in the human respiratory tract and compared it to nerves and cells containing classical neurotransmitters or peptides. Trachea, bronchus and lung were obtained from fresh human abortuses, 7-16 (n=19) and 17-24 wk gestation (n=11), from neonates (n=9), infants (n=6) and adults (n= 15). NSE-immunostaining was present in neuroblasts and nerve fibres in the earliest foetus examined (8wk). It remained as the neuroblasts matured into ganglion cells and the nerve fibres extended to end organs. Acetylcholinesterase staining was weak in neuroblasts, becoming stronger as they matured into ganglion cells. Dopamine-P-hydroxylase-positive nerve fibres appeared at 18-20 wk, while VIP-immunoreactive nerve fibres were seen only late in development and particularly after birth. NSE-immunoreactivity was present in well developed neuroendocrine cells in the airway epithelium at 8 wk gestation and increased in number up to birth, gradually declining in adult lung. Bombesin-immunoreactivity was detected in these cells later than NSE-immunoreactivity. NSE-immunoreactivity is thus present from early gestation, appearing before classical neurotransmitters or peptides, and should prove useful in investigating the developmental pattern of the lung neuroendocrine system in health and disease.

body_text.text: Two peptides have been recently isolated from porcine intestine. The first of these, designated PHI (peptide histidine isoleucine) shares sequence homology with VIP and has similar actions. The other peptide, NPY (neuropeptide with ty-rosine terminals), shares sequence homology with pancreatic polypeptide and is a powerful vasoconstrictor. We used immunocytochemistry and radioimmunoassay to investigate whether these peptides are present in the mammalian respiratory tract. Trachea, bronchus and lung were obtained from adult cats ( n = l l ) , rats (n=8), guinea-pigs (n=6) and human adults (n=15). Antibodies to natural porcine PHI and NPY were raised in rabbits. Preabsorption of each antiserum with its corresponding peptide abolished the immunostaining whereas addition of related peptides did not. PHI-immunoreactive ganglion cells and nerve fibres were present throughout the respiratory tract of all species, in the adventitia, around seromucous glands, in smooth muscle and blood vessels. NPYimmunoreactivity was localised to nerve fibres in the adventitia of blood vessels and airway smooth muscle. Radioimmunoassay showed significant concentrations of PHI and NPY in the mammalian respiratory tract. For example, PHI levels were high in the trachea and bronchus (32 k 9 pmol/g and 34 k 9 pmol/g in cat) with lower concentrations in the lung (19 k 2 pmol/g in cat). These results confirm the presence of two newly discovered pulmonary peptides, whose actions may be important in normal lung function.

body_text.text: Sections from 854 thoracotomies for lung cancer between 1968 and 1972 have been reviewed. 135 small cell carcinomas were identified of which 99 were resected and 14 survived 5 yr post-operatively. The identification of 135 small cell carcinomas required a change from the histological cell type originally allocated in over 20% of cases. We have identified a small but important group of cases in which the histological appearances lie between those of the classical carcinoid tumour and the small cell carcinoma. These 'atypical carcinoid tumours' have a better prognosis than sma!l cell, 45% surviving 5 yr after surgery. The small cell carcinomas are sub-divided into the two main sub-groups recognised in the WHO Classification (1981) . Other histological features such as tumour necrosis, presence of DNA cuffing around the vessels, and the presence of differentiation as shown by a rosette formation were studied in an attempt to correlate these histological fearures with survival after resection. NPY was mainly distributed in the dorsolateral funiculus and laminae V; Some nerve fibres were also seen in laminae I and 11. Neuropeptide Y (NPY) is a newly discovered peptide which is widely distributed in neuronal cell bodies and terminals of the central and peripheral nervous systems. Its distribution is similar to that of adrenergic nerves and, in some cases, the peptide and amine have shown co-localisation in the same cell. We report here on the immunocytochemical localisation of NPY-immunoreactivity to fibres in the uvea of guinea pig and rat, and on its relationship to sympathetic nerves. Whole mount preparations of iris and choroid were immunostained using an NPY antiserum, while adrenergic nerves were immunocytochemically identified with antibodies to tyrosine hydroxylase (TH). In the iris of both animals, NPY-immunoreactivity was localised to a dense plexus of fibres in dilator and constrictor pupillae muscles, and surrounding the irridial blood vessels. NPY-immunoreactive nerves were also seen throughout the choroid of both species, mainly along and around the numerous blood vessels. In both iris and choroid the number and distribution of NPY-immunoreactive fibres was very similar to that observed for TH-immunoreactive nerves. These results confirm the presence in the eye of NPY-immunoreactive nerves, whose morphological similarity to TH-immunoreactive nerves is consistent with the neurophysiological findings, which suggest a modulatory action of NPY on adrenergic neurons.

In the human calcitonin precursor molecule, calcitonin is flanked at the amino-and carboxy-terminals by peptides. Addition of calcitonin or other known pulmonary peptides did not diminish immunostaining. Numerous katalcin-immunoreactive cells were found in the airway epithelium of human neonatal lung, with fewer cells in foetal or adult lung. All katacalcin-containing cells were also immunoreactive for calcitonin. We have therefore demonstrated that the C-terminal flanking peptide of the human calcitonin precursor is present in the human lung and is co-localised with calcitonin in the same mucosal endocrine cells.

body_text.text: Age-related changes in human breast morphology have been quantitated by applying simple point counting and planimetry techniques at the sub-gross and light microscopic levels. Post-mortem samples from the second to the eighth decades were examined to assess: (1) the distribution of breast epithelium within the whole gland; (2) the relative amounts of epithelial components (acinar, terminal ductule and extralobular ducts), connective tissue (intra-and extra-lobular) and fat within each quadrant and (3) some shape and size characteristics of breast lobules. The sub-gross analysis revealed that in most age categories there was an uneven distribution of total epithelium within the breast with lower exceeding upper quadrants. At the light microscopic level age-related changes in the size of the lobule, were recorded. These latter findings were presumed to be associated with the process of maturation and involution. The results provide a basic quantitative model of human breast development during adult life by which various physiological and pathological changes may be assessed.

Leech St. George's Hospital Medical School, London SWl7 ORE Echocardiography has advanced clinical understanding both of the mechanisms of aortic and mitral regurgitation and of left ventricular shape. The technique has been described as 'living pathology'. Unfortunately the planes of section used in life bear no relation to the standard pathological dissection. Since the planes of echo-cardiography are governed by access between ribs or above the sternum, pathologists who wish to collaborate with the clinician must perforce adopt new techniques. If the heart is fixed before dissection by pressure perfusion via the aorta a specimen is obtained in which the aortic and mitral valves are in the closed position. Not only can correlation with echocardiograms be made but the pathology of aortic root dilation and mitral valve prolapse is strikingly demonstrated. Transection of the specimen in the long axis through the anterior cusp of the mitral valve gives a plane identical both to M mode and 2D echocardiograms. The left ventricular outflow and apical or posterior aneurysms are demonstrated in a manner identical to that seen in life. Transection of the ventricles in the short axis allows measurement of cavity size and wall thickness. The measurements correlate well with those taken in life. Both axes can be examined in one heart if the specimen is reconstituted after the first cut using superglue.

back_matter.text: Neuropeptide Y (NPY) is a newly discovered peptide of the pancreatic polypeptide family present in mammalian brain in higher concentration than any other neuropeptide hitherto described. Immunocytochemical studies have shown the peptide to have a widespread yet discrete distribution and have revealed NPY-immunoreactive fibres in long projecting pathways in the brain. The stria terminalis is the major efferent pathway from the aitiygdaloid complex and possesses NPY-immunoreactive fibres in both its dorsal and ventral portions. We have examined the possible terminal projection of these fibres by experimental lesions of the stria terminalis pathway. Observations were made on cryostat sections of rat brain fixed by perfusion with 4% paraformaldehyde and immunostained for NPY by the peroxidase anti-peroxidase technique. Stereotactic knife lesions were performed under Sagatal anaesthesia to transect the stria terminalis unilaterally at co-ordinates 4.0-5.0 mm anterior, 2.5 mm lateral and 5.00 mm depth with respect to the intraaural line. The contralateral stria served as an internal animal control. Rats were allowed to survive post-operatively for 10 days. A loss of NPYimmunoreactive fibres after lesioning was observed most predominantly in the bed nuclei of the stria terminalis and anterior commissure. Fewer fibres wealso apparent in the preoptic regions of the hypothalamus. The majority of NPY fibres in the stria terminalis, therefore, form a diffuse amygdalofugal projection to the forebrain, terminating most abundantly in the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis and preoptic hypothalamus. NPY may play a role, therefore, in amygdaloid control of hypothalamic function.

back_matter.text: A retrospective analysis of patients surviving 16 to 20 yr after diagnosis and treatment of primary beast cancer was undertaken to identify features associated with good prognosis. From 1959 to 1963, 626 patients were treated by simple mastectomy and radiotherapy and 138 (23%) of these were alive at December 1979. Histology was available for 133 and 14 (10.5%) were judged to have benign disease. The 119 carcinomas were assessed for histological type and other features namely elastosis, fibrosis, necrosis, vascular or lymphatic invasion and nuclear grade. A similar classification was carried out on 1050 consecutive primary breast carcinomas treated from 1960 to 1970, and the same histological features eveluated for 200 who survived for less than 10 yr. There was a predominance of special histological types in the survivor group (54%) in contrast to the 200 dying within 10 yr (10.5) and to the major consecutive group of 1050 (24%). Taking other factors influencing survival into account by multivariate analsis the most significant histological feature identifying long term survival was special histological type. In addition to non-invasive cancer, the special invasive histological pure (or classical) types more common in the survivors were those of tubular, cribriform, medullary and lobular types.

M.Forrest Departments of Pathology and Clinical Surgery, University of Edinburgh, Edinburgh EH8 9AG Screening for breast cancer among women aged 45-64yr has been carried out in Edinburgh since 1979 as part of a randomised trial. 147 cancers have been diagnosed in 'invited' well women and 100 of the mastectomies have been studied to assess the frequency of multifocal cancer. The method employed serial 'bread loaf' slices and their radiographs for multiple paraffin block selection to give a reconstruction map for the distribution of other foci of cancer. Multifocal cancer was detected in 33 cases (33%) the incidence being similar among the non-invasive and the invasive cancers. It was possible to identify the other foci as other primaries in all but two instances. In non-invasive cancer other foci were more likely to be confined to the reference tumour quadrant (RTQ) whilst the invasive cancers showed other quadrant turnour (OQT) more frequently. One case with an occult invasive focus occurred in the non-invasive cancers. Of 5 microinvasive cancers, the 2 with OQT had a reference lesion diameter greater than 25 mm. The nipple region was involved in 11 cases; in 4 of these it was the region of primary involvement, but in 5 of the others there was multifocal cancer involving OQT. Histological type of invasive cancer was not a reliable index on multifocal disease on its own, nor was lymph node status. These results have implications for selection into trials of conservation therapy and suggest that cases of non-invasive carcinoma or of invasive carcinomas less than 20mm that are lymph node negative will do best. Such cases comprise 55% of cancers occurring in a screening programme. Traditional methods include the use of more or less specific staining procedures as well as examination in polarized light. The important potential of energy dispersive X-ray microanalyis (EDX) has not been much exploited. This is probably in part due to the cumbersome and time-consuming processing currently in use for electron microscopy. However, paraffin sections may be directly examined in the electron microscope using t.he STEM mode giving an image which is very similar to the light microscopic appearance of the same section. A 3 km section is cut from a paraffin block and floated on water in the conventional way. The previously marked area of interest is carefully located on a Formvar/poly-1-lysine coated 'grid retainer'. The latter consists of a grid glued onto a perforated graphite plate which fits directly into the specimen holder of the electron microscope, Following deparaffinization and appropriate staining the section is mounted in water or glycerine and examined in the light microscope. Particles to be analyzed are sought and their precise localization recorded by drawing or photography. After dehydration and drying the same section is examined in the electron microscope and X-ray spectra obtained.
